channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Whatever Happened to the Starter Home?
item.description: The economics of the housing market, and the local rules that shape it, have squeezed out entry-level homes.

item.title: Sundance Liked Her Documentary, ‘Jihad Rehab,’ Until Muslim Critics Didn’t
item.description: The film festival gave Meg Smaker’s “Jihad Rehab” a coveted spot in its 2022 lineup, but apologized after an outcry over her race and her approach.
item.dc:creator: Michael Powell
item.media:credit: Tai Power Seeff for The New York Times
item.media:description: After criticism by Arab American and Muslim filmmakers led to the film being shunned by festivals, Meg Smaker renamed her documentary “The UnRedacted.”

item.title: Ukraine Fights to Reclaim Territory as Russia Holds Annexation Referendums
item.description: Ukraine’s president has urged citizens to resist the Russians in occupied territories, where voting is underway in what Western officials have called “sham” referendums on joining Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in an armored vehicle in Izium on Saturday.

item.title: How a Hospital Chain Used a Poor Neighborhood to Turn Huge Profits
item.description: Bon Secours Mercy Health, a major nonprofit health system, used the poverty of Richmond Community Hospital’s patients to tap into a lucrative federal drug program.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mel Haasch; Photograph by Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times

item.title: They Were Entitled to Free Care. Hospitals Hounded Them to Pay.
item.description: With the help of a consulting firm, the Providence hospital system trained staff to wring money out of patients, even those eligible for free care.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mel Haasch; Photographs by Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times

item.title: Why Iranians Are Protesting Once Again
item.description: Amid growing repression, a sickly economy and bleak prospects, the death of one young woman was all it took.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: Italy May Get a Leader With Post-Fascist Roots
item.description: With the hard-right candidate Giorgia Meloni ahead before Sunday’s election, Italy could get its first leader whose party traces its roots to the wreckage of Fascism.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Andreas Solaro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of Giorgia Meloni at a joint rally on Thursday for the Brothers of Italy, League and Forza Italia parties in Rome.

item.title: Kyoto Wants You Back, but It Has Some Polite Suggestions
item.description: The city, one of Japan’s most-visited before the pandemic, desperately needs tourism’s money, but it would like to avoid the excesses of Instagram-driven itineraries.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Andrew Faulk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before the pandemic, Kyoto’s Kiyomizu Temple was as famous for its congestion as for its sublime architecture and spectacular view of the city below.

item.title: This Surveillance Artist Knows How You Got That Perfect Instagram Photo
item.description: A tech-savvy artist unearthed video footage of people working hard to capture the perfect shot for Instagram. It is a lesson in the artifice of social media and the ubiquity of surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill

item.title: Poundbury, England: The Town That Charles Built
item.description: Before King Charles III inherited Britain’s throne, he was a prince with strong views on architecture. Poundbury is where he tried to put them into practice.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Mother Square in Poundbury, a small town in Dorset, southern England. Poundbury is relatively new — construction on it began in the 1990s — but it has a range of historical styles of architecture.

item.title: Do Not Bring Your ‘Whole Self’ to Work
item.description: Beware the latest fad from Human Resources.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: In Washington State, the Midterm Race Between Joe Kent and Marie Gluesenkamp Perez Has It All
item.description: This congressional race in Washington State shows the November elections in microcosm.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times

item.title: Putin and Trump, the Solo Soulless Saboteurs
item.description: Putin and Trump, dragging the world down with them.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yury Kochetkov

item.title: This Threat to Democracy Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Trump and his allies are trying to take over the machinery of American elections.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by Stephen Maturen, via Getty Images

item.title: My Parents Are Hackers Out of Necessity
item.description: Both skateboarding and navigating daily life with a disability involve surprisingly similar ways of engaging with the built environment.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Klemin

item.title: What Putin’s Nuclear Threat Means for Ukraine and the U.S.
item.description: Russia is flailing and losing. The nuclear threat is growing.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Since You’ve Been Gone: What’s Next for the Royal Corgis?
item.description: Considering the future of the short yet noble canines.
item.dc:creator: Emily Flake
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Is There Too Much ‘Mental Health’ Awareness in the United States?
item.description: Has the term become so expansive as to be meaningless?
item.dc:creator: Huw Green
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie. Photographs from Getty Images

item.title: The Morning: The back story of the migrant buses
item.description: Republican governors’ immigration stunts are actually helping some migrants.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lever Alejos, 29, from Venezuela, is one of the thousands of migrants who arrived on buses sent by the governors of Texas and Arizona last month near Capitol Hill.

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Quest by Circadian Medicine to Make the Most of Our Body Clocks’
item.description: Researchers are trying to figure out the right hour of the day to do everything. Can their studies sync us up with better health?
item.dc:creator: Kim Tingley, Jack D’Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Marion Lozano and Quinton Kamara
item.media:credit: Concept by Pablo Delcan. Photo Illustration by Bobby Doherty for The New York Times.

item.title: You Need Only 7 Ingredients
item.description: Make the most out of very little.
item.dc:creator: Emily Weinstein
item.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: A global ‘disconnect’ in full view
item.description: World leaders gathered in New York this week. Developing countries took the opportunity to demand more support and stronger action.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, on Tuesday at the 77th session of the General Assembly. He called the climate crisis the “defining issue of our time.”

item.title: Deadlier Than the Titanic: A Ferry Set Out With About 1,900 Aboard. Only 64 Survived.
item.description: Tourists, vendors, babies, hundreds of university students and a soccer team from Senegal perished in a little-known ferry disaster 20 years ago. Survivors and families of victims still want justice.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kantene cemetery in Ziguinchor, Senegal, has 42 graves of victims of the wreck. Artists paid tribute to the deceased by painting on the walls this year.

item.title: Eliud Kipchoge Smashes His Own World Record at the Berlin Marathon
item.description: Kipchoge ran the Berlin Marathon in a time of 2:01:09. Tigist Assefa shocked the women’s field by running her second marathon in 2:15:38, a course record.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Christoph Soeder/Associated Press
item.media:description: Eliud Kipchoge added another win, and another world record, to his marathon résumé.

item.title: Why Japan Is Angry About a State Funeral for Shinzo Abe
item.description: The fallout from Shinzo Abe’s death has taken a number of unexpected turns, casting a critical light on both his long-governing party and a fringe religious group.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against the planned state funeral for Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister, in Tokyo on Monday. Many are voicing their critique of his actions in life by opposing the effort to honor him in death.

item.title: The New India: Expanding Influence Abroad, Straining Democracy at Home
item.description: As India rises, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has faced little pushback as he weaponizes institutions to consolidate power and entrench his Hindu nationalist vision.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergei Bobylev/Sputnik/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting in Uzbekistan this month.

item.title: Is Natural Wine Actually Better for You?
item.description: Fewer headaches. Less severe hangovers. Better gut health. How do these health claims stack up against the science?
item.dc:creator: Jesse Hirsch
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: When Should I Get the New Bivalent Booster?
item.description: You are allowed to get the shot two months after a previous dose, but some experts suggest waiting a little longer.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

item.title: How to Exercise Safely Outside in the Fall and Winter
item.description: Here are a few ways to protect yourself from the elements, oncoming traffic and other threats that ramp up in the fall and winter months.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: ‘Preventative’ Botox: Do Injections Work to Reduce Wrinkles?
item.description: Or are injections just a temporary, addictive fix?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Fentanyl and Why It’s So Dangerous
item.description: Drug overdoses have reached record highs. Experts offer tips to talk about opioids with your family.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega, Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: For Two College Students, Finally a Place (and a Person) to Call Home
item.description: Yolka Gessen and Mohamad Eisa were nearly introduced by journalist Masha Gessen, who is the bride’s parent. But they found each other first.
item.dc:creator: Louise Rafkin
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohamad Eisa, a Syrian refugee, and Yolka Gessen, who was raised in Moscow until age 12, were married at Bard College, where both are students, on Sept. 10.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
